Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.

countermeasure.name: Follow just enough administration (least privilege) principle
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) to manage Azure resource access through role assignments. Through RBAC, you can assign roles to users, groups, service principals, and managed identities. There are pre-defined built-in roles for certain resources, and these roles can be inventoried or queried through tools such as Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure portal.
The privileges you assign to resources through Azure RBAC should always be limited to what's required by the roles. Limited privileges will complement the just-in-time (JIT) approach of Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM), and those privileges should be reviewed periodically. If required, you can also use PIM to define a time-bound assignment, which is a condition in a role assignment where a user can only activate the role within the specified start and end dates.
Note: Use Azure built-in roles to allocate permissions and only create custom roles when required.

countermeasure.name: Separate and limit highly privileged/administrative users
countermeasure.desc:
You must secure all roles with direct or indirect administrative access to Azure hosted resources.
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's default identity and access management service. The most critical built-in roles in Azure AD are Global Administrator and Privileged Role Administrator, because users assigned to these two roles can delegate administrator roles. With these privileges, users can directly or indirectly read and modify every resource in your Azure environment: - Global Administrator / Company Administrator: Users with this role have access to all administrative features in Azure AD as well as services that use Azure AD identities. - Privileged Role Administrator: Users with this role can manage role assignments in Azure AD, as well as within Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM). In addition, this role allows management of all aspects of PIM and administrative units.
Outside of Azure AD, Azure has built-in roles that can be critical for privileged access at the resource level. - Owner: Grants full access to manage all resources, including the ability to assign roles in Azure RBAC. - Contributor: Grants full access to manage all resources, but does not allow you to assign roles in Azure RBAC, manage assignments in Azure Blueprints, or share image galleries. - User Access Administrator: Lets you manage user access to Azure resources. Note: You may have other critical roles that need to be governed if you use custom roles in the Azure AD level or resource level with certain privileged permissions assigned.
In addition, users with the following three roles in Azure Enterprise Agreement (EA) portal should also be restricted as they can be used to directly or indirectly manage Azure subscriptions. - Account Owner: Users with this role can manage subscriptions, including the creation and deletion of subscriptions. - Enterprise Administrator: Users assigned with this role can manage (EA) portal users. - Department Administrator: Users assigned with this role can change account owners within the department.
Lastly, ensure that you also restrict privileged accounts in other management, identity, and security systems that have administrative access to your business-critical assets, such as Active Directory Domain Controllers (DCs), security tools, and system management tools with agents installed on business-critical systems. Attackers who compromise these management and security systems can immediately weaponize them to compromise business critical assets.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure certificate management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control the certificate lifecycle, including the creation/import, rotation, revocation, storage, and purge of the certificate. Ensure the certificate generation follows the defined standard without using any insecure properties, such as insufficient key size, overly long validity period, insecure cryptography and so on. Setup automatic rotation of the certificate in Azure Key Vault and supported Azure services based on the defined schedule and when a certificate expires. If automatic rotation is not supported in the frontend application, use a manual rotation in Azure Key Vault.
Avoid using a self-signed certificate and wildcard certificate in your critical services due to the limited security assurance. Instead, you can create public signed certificates in Azure Key Vault. The following Certificate Authorities (CAs) are the partnered providers that are currently integrated with Azure Key Vault. - DigiCert: Azure Key Vault offers OV TLS/SSL certificates with DigiCert. - GlobalSign: Azure Key Vault offers OV TLS/SSL certificates with GlobalSign.
Note: Use only approved CA and ensure that known bad root/intermediate certificates issued by these CAs are disabled.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and service disruption via API misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat arises from insecure configurations across API Management resources in Azure, which can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and service disruption.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious actors or unauthorized users attempting to exploit misconfigured API Management resources. Attack vectors may involve unauthorized access to sensitive data, modification of APIs, or disruption of services.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive data, potential data breaches, disruption of services, and potential compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a misconfigured API Management resource to gain unauthorized access to sensitive customer data, leading to a data breach and reputational damage to the organization. Another scenario involves an attacker modifying APIs through insecure configurations, leading to service disruption and potential financial losses for the organization.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data exposure due to weak API authentication
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access and potential compromise of API Management resources due to inadequate or misconfigured authentication and access control mechanisms in Azure API Management.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents could be external attackers, malicious insiders, or unauthorized users who attempt to exploit misconfigurations in the Azure API Management environment to gain unauthorized access to sensitive resources. Attack vectors may include brute-force attacks, token manipulation, or social engineering to trick developers or administrators into disclosing sensitive information.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat could result in unauthorized access to APIs, exposure of sensitive data, potential data breaches, and unauthorized execution of operations within the API Management environment. Additionally, compromised secrets stored in an insecure manner, such as hardcoded or weakly protected within the API Management, could lead to further compromise of sensitive data.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may attempt to exploit misconfigured OAuth 2.0 protocol with Azure AD authentication in the API Management instance to gain unauthorized access to protected APIs. They could also target the Azure Key Vault integration to gain access to stored secrets and manipulate the configurations, leading to potential data leaks or unauthorized use of the exposed APIs. Additionally, inadequate control over developer accounts and subscriptions could lead to unauthorized access and misuse of the APIs managed by the API Management platform.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and service disruption due to weak access control and local admin misuse
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access and mismanagement of Azure API Management resources and entities due to ineffective access control and unnecessary local admin account usage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents targeting this control could include malicious insiders, external attackers, or accidental misconfigurations. Attack vectors may involve exploiting misconfigured Azure RBAC permissions, compromising local admin accounts, or unauthorized escalation of privileges.
Impacts
The impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive API Management resources, potential data breaches, manipulation of APIs and policies, and disruption of service availability. Misuse of local admin accounts could result in excessive privileges, unauthorized changes, and potential compromise of emergency access mechanisms.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker exploits misconfigured Azure RBAC permissions to gain unauthorized access to critical API Management resources, such as sensitive APIs and policies, allowing them to modify or exfiltrate sensitive data. 2. A malicious insider abuses unrestricted local admin accounts for routine operations, leading to unauthorized configuration changes and potential service disruptions in Azure API Management during non-emergency situations.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to sensitive information in Azure Key Vault
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access to sensitive information such as secrets, certificates, and keys stored in Azure Key Vault, leading to potential misuse or exploitation by threat actors.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized entities attempting to gain access to the secrets, certificates, and keys stored in Azure Key Vault. Attack vectors could involve exploits targeting vulnerabilities in the Azure Key Vault, misconfigured access controls, or interception of communication channels.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information, potential compromise of API Management services, and potential breaches of confidentiality and integrity of critical resources. Additionally, the compromise of certificates and keys could lead to impersonation attacks, data breaches, and unauthorized system access.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits misconfigured access controls in Azure Key Vault to gain unauthorized access to the stored secrets, certificates, and keys. Using the compromised credentials, the attacker can then access, update, or misuse the sensitive information, potentially leading to unauthorized access to API Management and its associated resources. Furthermore, if automatic rotation of certificates and keys is not properly implemented, the attacker may exploit expired or weak credentials to gain access, bypass security controls, and compromise the integrity and confidentiality of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized public network access to API management service
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access to the API Management service or its resources from the public network, potentially leading to unauthorized usage, data breaches, or service disruption.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat may be posed by malicious actors attempting to directly access the API Management service from the public internet, bypassing any network security controls in place.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include potential unauthorized usage of the API Management service, data breaches, or service disruption due to unauthorized access from the public network.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could attempt to exploit open ports or misconfigured access controls to gain unauthorized access to the API Management service from the public internet. This could lead to unauthorized usage of APIs, data breaches, or disruption of the API Management service.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of comprehensive resource logs for the service increases the difficulty in detecting unauthorized access, malicious activities, or potential security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit the absence of resource logs to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or compromise the integrity and availability of the service. Attack vectors may include attempts to access secrets, sensitive information, or execute unauthorized commands within the service.
Impacts
The absence of detailed resource logs increases the risk of undetected security breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromised service integrity. This can result in data leaks, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a Key Vault and retrieves sensitive secrets undetected due to the absence of resource logs, resulting in unauthorized access to critical information. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting the lack of resource logs in an Azure SQL database to perform undetected malicious activities, potentially leading to data exfiltration or service disruption.

countermeasure.name: Follow just enough administration (least privilege) principle
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) to manage Azure resource access through role assignments. Through RBAC, you can assign roles to users, groups, service principals, and managed identities. There are pre-defined built-in roles for certain resources, and these roles can be inventoried or queried through tools such as Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure portal. The privileges you assign to resources through Azure RBAC should always be limited to what's required by the roles. Limited privileges will complement the just-in-time (JIT) approach of Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM), and those privileges should be reviewed periodically. If required, you can also use PIM to define a time-bound assignment, which is a condition in a role assignment where a user can only activate the role within the specified start and end dates. Note: Use Azure built-in roles to allocate permissions and only create custom roles when required.

countermeasure.name: Separate and limit highly privileged/administrative users
countermeasure.desc:
You must secure all roles with direct or indirect administrative access to Azure hosted resources.
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's default identity and access management service. The most critical built-in roles in Azure AD are Global Administrator and Privileged Role Administrator, because users assigned to these two roles can delegate administrator roles. With these privileges, users can directly or indirectly read and modify every resource in your Azure environment: - Global Administrator / Company Administrator: Users with this role have access to all administrative features in Azure AD as well as services that use Azure AD identities. - Privileged Role Administrator: Users with this role can manage role assignments in Azure AD, as well as within Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM). In addition, this role allows management of all aspects of PIM and administrative units.
Outside of Azure AD, Azure has built-in roles that can be critical for privileged access at the resource level. - Owner: Grants full access to manage all resources, including the ability to assign roles in Azure RBAC. - Contributor: Grants full access to manage all resources, but does not allow you to assign roles in Azure RBAC, manage assignments in Azure Blueprints, or share image galleries. - User Access Administrator: Lets you manage user access to Azure resources. Note: You may have other critical roles that need to be governed if you use custom roles in the Azure AD level or resource level with certain privileged permissions assigned.
In addition, users with the following three roles in Azure Enterprise Agreement (EA) portal should also be restricted as they can be used to directly or indirectly manage Azure subscriptions. - Account Owner: Users with this role can manage subscriptions, including the creation and deletion of subscriptions. - Enterprise Administrator: Users assigned with this role can manage (EA) portal users. - Department Administrator: Users assigned with this role can change account owners within the department.
Lastly, ensure that you also restrict privileged accounts in other management, identity, and security systems that have administrative access to your business-critical assets, such as Active Directory Domain Controllers (DCs), security tools, and system management tools with agents installed on business-critical systems. Attackers who compromise these management and security systems can immediately weaponize them to compromise business critical assets.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unscheduled or infrequent application backups leading to potential data loss
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of data loss and downtime due to operational failure or security breaches is a concern with stateful applications, even if backup and recovery mechanisms are in place.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious actors seeking to disrupt or compromise the application and its data. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access to the application and its storage, injection of malicious code, or intentional deletion or corruption of data.
Impacts
The impacts of a successful attack or operational failure could include loss of data, extended downtime, potential regulatory non-compliance, and damage to the organization's reputation and trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the application and its backup data, leading to the theft or deletion of critical information. 2. Malicious code injection results in the corruption or encryption of application data, rendering backups unusable for recovery. 3. Operational failure, such as misconfiguration or human error, causes accidental deletion or overwriting of critical data, leading to service disruption.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data breaches due to public endpoints in Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS)
threat.desc:
General threat description
Disabling the Public FQDN on a private Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) cluster can help mitigate the risk of unauthorized access and potential exposure of the cluster to the public internet. Deploying private endpoints for Azure resources that support Private Link further enhances the security posture by providing a private access point for the resources, reducing the exposure to public networks and potential threats. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may attempt to gain unauthorized access to the Azure Kubernetes Service cluster or the associated Azure resources by leveraging public endpoints or exploiting potential vulnerabilities. Attack vectors may include unauthorized network access, reconnaissance, and exploitation of misconfigured public endpoints. 
Impacts
Disabling the Public FQDN and deploying private endpoints can help mitigate the risk of unauthorized access, data exfiltration, and potential exposure to external threats. Failure to implement these controls can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and exploitation of public endpoints. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker attempts to gain unauthorized access to an Azure Kubernetes Service cluster by leveraging the Public FQDN and exploiting potential vulnerabilities in publicly accessible components. Without private endpoints, the attacker may also attempt to intercept or manipulate data transmitted between the Azure resources and external clients.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Unauthorized use of Azure RBAC for resource access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Disabling or restricting local admin accounts for emergency use introduces the risk of unauthorized access and compromise of critical systems if emergency access is needed. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external threat actors may attempt to gain unauthorized access to systems by exploiting disabled or restricted local admin accounts. Attack vectors may include brute force attacks, privilege escalation, or exploiting vulnerabilities in other accounts or systems. 
Impacts
The compromise of disabled or restricted local admin accounts can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, system manipulation, or disruption of operations. This can result in financial loss, reputational damage, and non-compliance with security regulations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An insider threat actor with knowledge of emergency access procedures attempts to exploit the disabled local admin account during a critical system downtime, gaining unauthorized access and manipulating critical data. Alternatively, an external threat actor launches a brute force attack against disabled local admin accounts to gain unauthorized access to critical infrastructure.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data breaches due to insecure Azure resource configurations
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized or insecure configurations of Azure resources, leading to potential security vulnerabilities and non-compliance with organizational security policies. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors, insider threats, or accidental misconfigurations. Attack vectors may involve unauthorized access, misconfigured settings, or exploitation of vulnerabilities in Azure resources. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include increased risk of data breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive information, exposure of resources to potential attacks, and non-compliance with security standards and regulations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker exploits a misconfigured Azure storage account with publicly accessible data, leading to unauthorized access and data exfiltration. 2. An insider intentionally misconfigures an Azure virtual machine, allowing unauthorized access to the system and potential data manipulation. 3. A misconfiguration in an Azure Key Vault leads to unauthorized access to cryptographic keys, compromising the confidentiality and integrity of sensitive data.

threat.name: Data breaches and unauthorized access due to inadequate certificate lifecycle management and insecure encryption
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of inadequate management of certificate lifecycle, insecure encryption standards, and insecure transfer protocols can lead to potential data breaches, unauthorized access, and compromised data integrity in the cloud environment. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit inadequate management of certificate lifecycle, insecure encryption standards, and insecure transfer protocols through various means such as unauthorized access to keys and certificates, interception of data in transit, and exploitation of vulnerabilities in encryption algorithms. 
Impacts
The impacts of such threats include potential exposure of sensitive data, unauthorized access to critical systems, compromised data integrity, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker intercepts data in transit due to insecure transfer protocols and gains unauthorized access to sensitive information. 2. Exploiting inadequate key management practices, an attacker gains access to encryption keys and decrypts confidential data stored in the cloud environment. 3. Insecure encryption standards and long validity periods lead to the compromise of certificates, allowing malicious actors to impersonate legitimate services and conduct man-in-the-middle attacks.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data breaches from default authentication methods and insecure credential storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
The use of default authentication methods or insecure storage of secrets and credentials can lead to unauthorized access and potential data breaches in the cloud environment. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious actors, internal users with malicious intent, or automated bots targeting insecurely stored credentials. Attack vectors could involve exploiting vulnerabilities in code or configuration files where credentials are embedded, or leveraging unauthorized access to compromise the Azure AD or Key Vault. 
Impacts
The impacts of these threats could range from unauthorized access to sensitive data, data exfiltration, service disruptions, reputational damage, and regulatory non-compliance. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains access to code or configuration files containing embedded credentials, allowing them to extract the sensitive information and compromise the systems or data they protect. 2. A malicious insider exploits default authentication methods to gain unauthorized access to the data plane, bypassing security controls and accessing confidential information. 3. A threat actor successfully compromises the insecurely stored secrets and credentials in Azure Key Vault, leading to unauthorized access to critical resources or data.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of comprehensive resource logs for the service increases the difficulty in detecting unauthorized access, malicious activities, or potential security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit the absence of resource logs to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or compromise the integrity and availability of the service. Attack vectors may include attempts to access secrets, sensitive information, or execute unauthorized commands within the service.
Impacts
The absence of detailed resource logs increases the risk of undetected security breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromised service integrity. This can result in data leaks, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a Key Vault and retrieves sensitive secrets undetected due to the absence of resource logs, resulting in unauthorized access to critical information. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting the lack of resource logs in an Azure SQL database to perform undetected malicious activities, potentially leading to data exfiltration or service disruption.

This encryption is performed automatically without requiring application changes, making it a seamless and effective security control for protecting sensitive information.

threat.name: Unpatched software
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Unpatched software refers to running outdated versions of Azure SQL Server or its components that have known vulnerabilities. Attackers can exploit these vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access, compromise the system, or cause service disruptions. Regular software updates and patches are crucial to maintaining the security and integrity of the system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat agents: Cybercriminals, internal attackers, automated exploit bots
  • Attack vectors: Exploiting known vulnerabilities in unpatched versions of Azure SQL Server or other related components (e.g., operating system, database engine, third-party libraries) to execute attacks like privilege escalation, remote code execution, or SQL injection.

Impacts:

  • Data breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Malware deployment: Attackers can inject malicious code into the environment.
  • Denial of service: Exploiting vulnerabilities can lead to service disruptions or crashes.
  • Reputation damage: Breach of security can erode customer trust and lead to financial and regulatory consequences.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Exploitation of a Known SQL Server Vulnerability: An attacker uses an unpatched vulnerability in an outdated version of the SQL Server to exploit the system and gain access to confidential data.
  2. RCE via Unpatched Components: A vulnerability in a third-party library used by SQL Server allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code on the database server.
  3. Privilege Escalation: An attacker targets a known flaw in the SQL Server’s access control mechanism that has not been patched, elevating their privileges and gaining administrative control over the database.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring and logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Insufficient monitoring and logging in Azure SQL Server can prevent security teams from detecting and responding to malicious activity in a timely manner. Without comprehensive logs and real-time monitoring, attackers may go undetected, leading to unauthorized access, data breaches, or prolonged system compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat agents: Cybercriminals, insiders, automated bots
  • Attack vectors: Exploiting lack of visibility and detection systems by carrying out stealthy attacks such as privilege escalation, data exfiltration, or SQL injection. Attackers may also disable or manipulate logs to evade detection.

Impacts:

  • Delayed detection of security breaches: Inability to identify attacks early, resulting in extended exposure to threats.
  • Lack of forensic evidence: Missing logs hinder post-incident analysis, making it difficult to understand the scope and method of the attack.
  • Regulatory non-compliance: Insufficient logging may violate data protection regulations that require comprehensive audit trails for security monitoring.
  • Increased risk of undetected attacks: Ongoing attacks may remain unnoticed, leading to extensive damage.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. SQL Injection Attack: An attacker exploits an SQL injection vulnerability, and due to insufficient logging, their malicious activity goes unnoticed until significant data is exfiltrated.
  2. Privilege Escalation: An insider exploits elevated privileges without detection because there is inadequate monitoring of user actions and permission changes in SQL Server logs.
  3. Malicious Activity by Bot: A bot performs brute-force attempts to gain unauthorized access to the SQL database. Lack of real-time monitoring prevents early detection, allowing the bot to continue its attempts undetected.

threat.name: SQL injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
SQL injection is a type of attack where an attacker exploits vulnerabilities in an application's input validation process to execute malicious SQL queries. These queries are designed to manipulate or bypass the normal functioning of the application and may grant unauthorized access to the database. In Azure SQL Server, a successful SQL injection attack can lead to unauthorized data access, modification, or even full administrative control of the database.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat agents: Cybercriminals, hackers, script kiddies
  • Attack vectors: Input fields (e.g., login forms, search bars) that are not properly sanitized or validated, allowing attackers to inject malicious SQL code.

Impacts:

  • Data breach: Attackers can retrieve sensitive information, such as personal details, passwords, and financial data.
  • Data manipulation: Malicious queries can modify, delete, or corrupt critical data, affecting the integrity of the database.
  • Privilege escalation: Attackers may use SQL injection to escalate privileges and gain administrative access to the system or underlying infrastructure.
  • Reputation damage: A successful attack can significantly damage the reputation of the organization, resulting in loss of customer trust.
  • Compliance violations: Exposure of sensitive data may violate data protection regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA), leading to legal and financial consequences.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Login Form Vulnerability: An attacker enters a specially crafted SQL query into a login form’s username or password field, bypassing authentication and gaining access to the system.
  2. Search Function Exploit: An attacker manipulates the search query in a website’s search bar, injecting SQL code to retrieve and exfiltrate customer data from the underlying Azure SQL database.
  3. Admin Privilege Escalation: An attacker uses SQL injection to manipulate a vulnerable web application, gaining admin-level privileges and potentially modifying or deleting critical data in the database.

threat.name: Sensitive data exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Sensitive data exposure occurs when Azure SQL Server does not properly protect confidential or personal information, such as passwords, credit card numbers, or healthcare records. Without strong encryption or other data protection mechanisms, attackers can intercept or access this sensitive data during storage, processing, or transmission.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat agents: Cybercriminals, insiders, state-sponsored actors
  • Attack vectors: Data theft through SQL injection, unauthorized access via weak authentication, interception of unencrypted data in transit, or physical theft of unprotected data storage.

Impacts:

  • Data breaches: Unauthorized access to sensitive information, leading to legal, financial, and reputational damage.
  • Regulatory non-compliance: Exposure of sensitive data may violate privacy regulations such as GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI-DSS, leading to penalties.
  • Identity theft: Personal identifiable information (PII) being exposed can be used for fraudulent activities or identity theft.
  • Financial losses: Leakage of credit card details or financial records can result in fraud or direct financial theft.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. SQL Injection Attack: An attacker uses a SQL injection vulnerability to retrieve unencrypted customer data from the Azure SQL Server, including passwords and credit card numbers.
  2. Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) Attack: Sensitive data transmitted over HTTP instead of HTTPS is intercepted by an attacker, exposing customer data such as account numbers and social security numbers.
  3. Insider Threat: A malicious insider with elevated privileges accesses sensitive financial data without authorization, storing or transmitting it for personal gain or selling it to third parties.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Unauthorized access occurs when an attacker gains access to resources, systems, or data without proper authorization. In Azure SQL Server, this can happen if security controls such as access management, authentication, or authorization mechanisms are improperly configured. This allows malicious users or attackers to gain access to databases, which could lead to data theft, modification, or destruction.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, external attackers
  • Attack vectors:
    • Weak authentication: Exploiting weak passwords, lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA), or inadequate identity management.
    • Inadequate access control policies: Users being granted excessive privileges, or incorrect Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) configurations.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities: Attackers exploiting known or zero-day vulnerabilities to bypass authentication and gain unauthorized access.
    • Social engineering or phishing: Obtaining credentials through phishing attacks or social engineering techniques.

Impacts:

  • Data breach: Unauthorized access can lead to exposure of sensitive data, including PII (Personally Identifiable Information), financial records, and business-critical information.
  • Data manipulation or deletion: Attackers can modify or delete data, potentially leading to data loss or corruption.
  • Privilege escalation: Unauthorized users might escalate their privileges to gain full access to the database or system, affecting the integrity of security controls.
  • Reputational damage: Exposure of sensitive data can severely damage the organization’s reputation and trust with customers.
  • Regulatory and financial penalties: Failure to protect data adequately can lead to compliance violations and result in fines or legal consequences.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Credential Theft: An attacker successfully steals login credentials via a phishing attack and accesses an Azure SQL database containing sensitive customer data.
  2. Excessive Privileges: An employee with unnecessary administrative access to the Azure SQL Server uses their privileges to export confidential data, leading to data leakage.
  3. Exploiting Vulnerabilities: An attacker takes advantage of an unpatched vulnerability in the SQL Server to bypass authentication and access the database, potentially leading to further exploitation or ransomware deployment.

usecase.name: Tampering

threat.name: Weak security configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Weak security configurations in Azure SQL Server occur when security settings, such as authentication, encryption, and network controls, are improperly configured. This leaves the server vulnerable to attacks and unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat agents: Cybercriminals, insiders, automated attack tools
  • Attack vectors:
    • Default or weak passwords
    • Misconfigured RBAC and access controls
    • Lack of encryption for data at rest or in transit
    • Improperly configured firewalls
    • Unpatched software vulnerabilities

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data
  • Data loss or corruption
  • Data leakage during transmission
  • Reputational damage and regulatory non-compliance

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker gains access through a weak password or default credential.
  2. Excessive user privileges lead to unauthorized data access.
  3. An unpatched vulnerability allows exploitation of the system.
  4. Sensitive data is intercepted because encryption is not enabled.

weakness.name: CWE-1004
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1004: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag The product uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag. The HttpOnly flag directs compatible browsers to prevent client-side script from accessing cookies. Including the HttpOnly flag in the Set-Cookie HTTP response header helps mitigate the risk associated with Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) where an attacker's script code might attempt to read the contents of a cookie and exfiltrate information obtained. When set, browsers that support the flag will not reveal the contents of the cookie to a third party via client-side script executed via XSS.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-521
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

threat.name: Weak security configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Weak security configurations in Azure Web Apps occur when default, outdated, or improperly set security options leave applications vulnerable to exploitation. This includes insecure authentication, permissive access controls, and lack of encryption for data transmission or storage.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Hackers, malicious insiders, automated bots.
  • Vectors: Exploiting default credentials, misconfigured access controls, or lack of encryption protocols.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive user or application data.
  • Service Compromise: Unauthorized access or tampering with app functionality.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Violations of data protection laws.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits an application with default credentials that were not changed after deployment.
  2. Weak permissions on resources allow unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  3. Lack of HTTPS results in sensitive data being intercepted during transmission.

threat.name: Unauthorized control of environment

Unauthorized control of the environment occurs when attackers gain the ability to manage and manipulate the Azure Web Apps environment, including configurations, resources, and deployments. This often results from misconfigurations, weak access controls, or compromised credentials.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insiders, automated scripts.
  • Vectors: Exploiting misconfigured permissions, stealing access tokens or keys, or compromising privileged accounts.

Impacts

  • Service Downtime: Disruption or unavailability of web applications.
  • Malicious Modifications: Deployment of malicious code or resources.
  • Data Breach: Access to sensitive data or configurations.
  • Operational Risks: Loss of control over application environments.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits a misconfigured role assignment to gain administrative privileges over the application.
  2. Stolen API keys are used to deploy unauthorized resources or tamper with existing deployments.
  3. A malicious insider deliberately alters configurations, causing a denial of service or unauthorized access.

General Threat Description
Unauthorized access to the root account occurs when attackers gain administrative control of Azure Web Apps, enabling them to alter configurations, access sensitive data, or deploy malicious applications. This often results from weak credentials, lack of multi-factor authentication, or leaked secrets.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Service Disruption: Altered or disabled application components.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of user trust.
  • Non-Compliance: Regulatory violations.

  2. Credentials leaked in a public GitHub repo are used to gain access.

threat.name: Data exposure during transmission

Data exposure during transmission occurs when sensitive information, such as user credentials or application data, is transmitted over unencrypted or poorly secured communication channels, making it susceptible to interception by attackers.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insiders, network eavesdroppers.
  • Vectors: Exploiting the use of HTTP, outdated encryption protocols, or insecure APIs.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Compromise of sensitive user or application data.
  • Man-in-the-Middle Attacks: Alteration or interception of data during transmission.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of data protection standards like GDPR or PCI DSS.

Example Attack Scenarios

  2. Weak TLS settings allow exploitation of known vulnerabilities to decrypt sensitive communications.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to data storage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized access to data storage occurs when attackers or unauthorized users gain access to databases or storage systems, allowing them to view, modify, or delete sensitive data. This can result from weak authentication, misconfigured permissions, or exposed endpoints.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, bots.
  • Vectors: Exploiting weak access controls, leaked credentials, or improperly secured storage configurations.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive information.
  • Data Tampering: Unauthorized modification of critical data.
  • Data Loss: Deletion or corruption of stored information.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from users or stakeholders.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits weak database credentials to gain unauthorized access.
  2. Misconfigured permissions on a storage bucket expose private files to public access.
  3. A malicious insider accesses customer data stored in the database without authorization.

threat.name: Unauthorized network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized network access occurs when attackers or unauthorized users gain entry to a network segment or system, potentially accessing sensitive resources or disrupting services. This can result from weak firewall rules, misconfigured security groups, or exposed network endpoints.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insiders, automated bots.
  • Vectors: Exploiting open ports, poorly configured network security rules, or vulnerabilities in exposed endpoints.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information.
  • Service Disruption: Interference with or downtime of network-dependent systems.
  • Lateral Movement: Attackers moving through the network to exploit additional systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker scans for open ports and gains access to an exposed database server due to misconfigured security group rules.
  2. A malicious insider uses lax firewall policies to bypass restrictions and access restricted systems.
  3. A botnet exploits an unprotected network endpoint to launch a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Insufficient logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insufficient logging and monitoring occurs when systems fail to adequately record or analyze activities, leading to undetected security incidents, delayed response times, and incomplete forensic investigations. This can stem from a lack of centralized logging, incomplete log data, or failure to set up alerting for suspicious activities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unmonitored automated processes.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized connection to the resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

This threat occurs when attackers establish unauthorized connections to resources managed by Microsoft Entra ID. Exploiting weak network policies, misconfigured access controls, or improperly secured APIs, attackers can connect to critical resources and potentially compromise data, applications, or infrastructure.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or automated bots.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) or conditional access policies.
    • Abusing unprotected APIs or endpoints.
    • Using stolen credentials or session tokens to bypass authentication mechanisms.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Connection to sensitive resources like databases, storage accounts, or virtual machines.
  • Data Compromise: Leakage, manipulation, or deletion of sensitive information.
  • Service Disruption: Overloading or tampering with resources, resulting in downtime or degraded performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses a compromised account with overly permissive RBAC permissions to access and exfiltrate data from cloud storage.
  2. An unprotected API connected to Entra ID allows an attacker to query sensitive system information without proper authentication.
  3. A misconfigured conditional access policy permits access from unauthorized IP ranges, enabling attackers to connect to internal resources.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized control of the environment
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

This threat arises when attackers exploit vulnerabilities or misconfigurations in Microsoft Entra ID to gain administrative or elevated control over the environment. With unauthorized control, attackers can modify configurations, create or delete resources, and compromise the integrity of the system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, insider threats, or Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs).
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting compromised privileged accounts through phishing or brute force attacks.
    • Misusing default or improperly configured administrative roles.
    • Exploiting gaps in identity protection policies, such as unmonitored role assignments.

Impacts

  • Environment Takeover: Full control of resources, including the ability to modify or delete critical configurations.
  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data across the organization.
  • Operational Disruption: Disabling security mechanisms, disrupting services, or deploying malicious configurations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to a global administrator account through a successful phishing attack and disables security policies like Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA).
  2. A misconfigured administrative role allows an attacker with limited access to escalate privileges and control the Entra ID environment.
  3. Default administrative credentials for an integrated service are exploited, enabling attackers to create malicious policies or users within the directory.

  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and stakeholders.

threat.name: Exploitation of insufficient logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

This threat arises when attackers exploit gaps in logging and monitoring mechanisms within Microsoft Entra ID. Insufficient or improperly configured logging allows malicious activities, such as unauthorized access or data tampering, to go undetected, delaying response and mitigation efforts.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, insider threats, or Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs).
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting unmonitored or improperly configured logging settings.
    • Using low-and-slow attack techniques to avoid detection due to insufficient monitoring rules.
    • Targeting systems without centralized logging or alerting mechanisms.

Impacts

  • Delayed Threat Detection: Critical security incidents remain unnoticed.
  • Data Breaches: Unauthorized actions lead to exposure or theft of sensitive information.
  • Operational Impact: Failure to identify and respond to threats can disrupt business operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses compromised credentials to log into a privileged account; the event goes unnoticed due to the absence of sign-in log auditing.
  2. A misconfigured storage account is accessed by unauthorized users, but the lack of logging prevents the detection of data exfiltration.
  3. Malware spreads laterally through connected systems undetected due to the absence of centralized monitoring and anomaly detection.

usecase.name: Spoofing

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to the user account due to the lack of configuration of the account
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

This threat occurs when attackers exploit improperly configured user accounts in Microsoft Entra ID, such as those without strong authentication or password policies. Weak configurations can leave accounts vulnerable to unauthorized access, compromising organizational security.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, insider threats, or automated credential attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Brute-force attacks against accounts with weak or default passwords.
    • Exploiting accounts lacking multi-factor authentication (MFA).
    • Leveraging unmonitored or inactive accounts for unauthorized access.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain entry to sensitive resources and systems.
  • Data Breaches: Theft or exposure of sensitive information linked to compromised accounts.
  • Operational Impact: Use of compromised accounts to execute malicious actions or disrupt operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A user account with no MFA enabled is compromised through a brute-force attack, allowing unauthorized access to cloud resources.
  2. Default credentials for a newly created account are not updated, enabling an attacker to log in and exfiltrate sensitive data.
  3. An unmonitored, inactive account is exploited by an attacker to move laterally within the environment and compromise other systems.

threat.name: Attackers perform unauthorized network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

This threat occurs when attackers exploit weak or misconfigured network controls to gain unauthorized access to systems or data. Inadequate protections, such as overly permissive firewall rules or unprotected endpoints, can expose critical resources to malicious activities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or automated bots.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Scanning for open ports or endpoints with insufficient access restrictions.
    • Exploiting misconfigured network security groups (NSGs) or firewall rules.
    • Leveraging stolen credentials to bypass network controls.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers infiltrate internal systems and resources.
  • Data Breaches: Sensitive data is accessed, modified, or stolen.
  • Service Disruption: Unauthorized activity can lead to downtime or degraded performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A misconfigured NSG allows inbound traffic on management ports (e.g., RDP, SSH) from the public internet, enabling attackers to attempt brute-force attacks.
  2. An overly permissive firewall rule exposes a database to the public internet, allowing unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  3. An unprotected API endpoint is discovered and exploited by attackers to extract system configurations.

To protect your web application from clickjacking and other iframe-based attacks, follow these steps to implement frame-busting scripts, set the X-Frame-Options HTTP header, and enforce Content Security Policy (CSP). These measures will prevent your web pages from being embedded within iframes on unauthorized websites, mitigating potential attacks.

Step 1: Employ Frame-Busting Scripts

Add Frame-Busting JavaScript: Within the <head> section of your HTML pages, include a JavaScript snippet that prevents your website from being framed. A simple script like this can be used:

This script checks if your page is being framed and, if so, redirects the top-level window to the current page, effectively "busting" out of the frame.

Step 2: Set X-Frame-Options Header

Configure Web Server: Depending on your web server, add a configuration to include the X-Frame-Options HTTP header in all responses. This header tells browsers not to embed your pages within frames or iframes. There are three options you can set:

  • DENY - No framing is allowed.
  • SAMEORIGIN - Only framing within the same domain is allowed.
  • ALLOW-FROM uri - Framing is allowed only by the specified uri.

Step 3: Enforce Content Security Policy

Implement CSP Header: Content Security Policy (CSP) is a powerful tool that helps prevent XSS attacks and other injection vulnerabilities. To prevent your pages from being framed, include the CSP frame-ancestors directive in your responses.

Configure Web Server to Include CSP: Add a CSP header with a frame-ancestors directive to define which origins can embed your content.

countermeasure.name: Implement input validation, output encoding, and enforce Content Security Policy (CSP)
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing input validation, output encoding, and enforcing Content Security Policy (CSP) are crucial steps to securing your web UI against a variety of common attacks, such as Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), SQL Injection, and others. Here's how to approach each countermeasure effectively:

Implement Input Validation

Input validation ensures that only properly formatted data is entered into your system. Follow these steps:

  1. Define Acceptable Input: Clearly specify what constitutes valid input for each field (e.g., types, lengths, formats, and ranges) in your application. Use regular expressions for pattern matching where applicable.
  2. Validate All Inputs: Apply validation to all received data, whether from users, files, or other systems. This includes data from forms, query parameters, cookies, and any external sources.
  3. Use Existing Libraries: Leverage existing, well-tested validation libraries and frameworks for your programming language or platform, rather than writing your own validation code from scratch.
  4. Reject Invalid Input: If input validation fails, reject the input, log the event for monitoring potential attacks, and provide user feedback that guides them toward correct input without revealing too much about the underlying validation logic or application architecture.

Implement Output Encoding

Output encoding transforms special characters into a safe format that prevents the browser from executing them as code. This is especially important to mitigate XSS attacks.

  1. Encode Data: Encode all dynamic data displayed to users, especially data that comes from user input, external systems, or databases. Use HTML entity encoding for content displayed in HTML.
  2. Use Context-Specific Encoding: The encoding method should match the context where the data is displayed (e.g., HTML, JavaScript, CSS, URL). Libraries like OWASP's ESAPI provide context-specific encoding functions.
  3. Adopt Secure Frameworks: Modern web frameworks often provide automatic output encoding. Familiarize yourself with and enable these features in your framework.

Enforce Content Security Policy (CSP)

CSP is a browser feature that helps detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including XSS and data injection attacks, by allowing web developers to declare which dynamic resources are allowed to load.

  1. Define a CSP Policy: Create a CSP policy that specifies which sources your web application is allowed to load resources from. Start with a strict policy that only allows resources from your domain, and then incrementally allow additional sources as needed.
  2. Use CSP Directives: Utilize directives like default-src, script-src, img-src, style-src, and others to control specific resources. Use the nonce attribute for inline scripts and styles if they are necessary.
  3. Test Your Policy: Before deploying, test your CSP policy to ensure it doesn't break your web application's functionality. Tools like Google Chrome's Developer Tools can help identify and debug CSP violations.
  4. Implement Reporting: CSP can be configured to send reports of policy violations to a server endpoint. This is invaluable for detecting and responding to attacks in real-time.

References and Good Practices

  • OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project): Refer to OWASP's guides and cheat sheets for detailed best practices on input validation, output encoding, and implementing CSP.
  • Web Framework Security Features: Use security features built into your web development framework. Frameworks like Django, Ruby on Rails, and ASP.NET have built-in protections against many common web vulnerabilities.
  • Continuous Education: Stay updated on the latest security practices and vulnerabilities affecting web applications. Regularly update your skills and your application's libraries and frameworks.

By following these guidelines, developers can significantly enhance the security of their web UI components against a range of common web vulnerabilities.

countermeasure.name: Implement strong authentication mechanisms and follow the least privilege principle
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your web UI, implementing strong authentication mechanisms is crucial. Follow these steps to ensure that access to your system is securely controlled.

Step 1: Use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)

Enable MFA: Ensure your authentication system supports Multi-Factor Authentication. MFA requires users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access, significantly increasing security.

Integrate with Trusted Providers: Use well-established MFA providers or frameworks that support various verification methods, such as SMS codes, email verification, authenticator apps, or hardware tokens.

Step 2: Enforce Strong Password Policies

Set Complexity Requirements: Define password policies that require a mix of upper and lower case letters, numbers, and special characters. Ensure passwords are of a minimum length (e.g., 12 characters).

Implement Account Lockout Mechanisms: To prevent brute force attacks, temporarily lock accounts after several unsuccessful login attempts.

Use Password Alternatives: Where possible, encourage or enforce the use of passphrase alternatives, biometrics, or other more secure authentication methods.

Step 3: Regularly Update Authentication Systems

Patch and Update: Keep your authentication systems up-to-date with the latest security patches and updates.

Audit and Review: Regularly audit authentication mechanisms for vulnerabilities. Use security scanning tools and consider external security audits.

Follow the Least Privilege Principle

The principle of least privilege ensures that users and systems have only the minimum levels of access—or permissions—needed to perform their tasks. This reduces the potential impact of a compromise.

Step 1: Define Access Levels

Identify Roles: Define clear roles within your application (e.g., user, admin, moderator) and specify the access level for each.

Assign Permissions: Assign permissions based on roles. Ensure that each role has the least amount of privilege necessary to perform its functions.

Step 2: Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)

Use RBAC Systems: Implement or utilize an existing RBAC system that allows for easy management of roles and permissions.

Regularly Review Access: Periodically review roles and permissions to ensure they are still appropriate for each user’s needs.

Step 3: Monitor and Audit Access

Logging: Ensure that access and activities are logged. Keep an audit trail that can be reviewed in the event of a security incident.

Alerts: Set up alerts for unusual access patterns or administrative actions, which can help in early detection of security breaches.

Additional Good Security Practices

  • Security Training: Regularly train developers and users on the importance of strong authentication practices and the principle of least privilege.
  • Use Secure Communication: Ensure that authentication data, such as passwords and tokens, are always transmitted over secure channels (e.g., HTTPS).
  • Periodic Security Assessments: Conduct periodic security assessments and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities in your authentication mechanism and access control policies.

Implementing these measures will significantly strengthen the security of your web UI by ensuring that only authorized users can access sensitive information and functionality, and that they can only perform actions necessary for their role.

countermeasure.name: Regularly update dependencies, use dependency scanning tools, and follow best practices for secure coding
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing a process to regularly update dependencies, utilize dependency scanning tools, and follow best practices for secure coding is essential in maintaining the security and integrity of your software. This proactive approach helps mitigate vulnerabilities, reduce the attack surface, and ensure the application remains robust against emerging threats. Here's how to approach each aspect effectively:

Regularly Update Dependencies

Dependencies, such as libraries and frameworks, are often updated to patch security vulnerabilities, fix bugs, and add new features. Keeping these dependencies up to date is crucial.

  1. Automate Updates: Use tools like Dependabot (GitHub), Renovate, or npm audit (for Node.js projects) to automate the detection of outdated dependencies. These tools can be configured to automatically create pull requests for updates.
  2. Subscribe to Vulnerability Alerts: Many platforms offer vulnerability alerts for project dependencies. Enable these alerts to be notified when a dependency needs to be updated due to a security issue.
  3. Regular Review: Schedule regular intervals (e.g., monthly or quarterly) to review and update dependencies, even if automated tools are in place. This ensures that updates don't introduce breaking changes or new vulnerabilities.

Use Dependency Scanning Tools

Dependency scanning tools analyze your project's dependencies for known vulnerabilities, licensing issues, and sometimes even code quality.

  1. Integrate Scanning into CI/CD Pipeline: Tools like Snyk, OWASP Dependency-Check, and SonarQube can be integrated into your Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) pipeline. This allows for automatic scanning of dependencies whenever code is committed or before deployment.
  2. Act on Findings: Prioritize and address the vulnerabilities found by scanning tools based on their severity. Some tools provide recommendations or even automated fixes for vulnerabilities.
  3. Audit Dependencies: Regularly audit your project's dependency tree to identify and remove unused or unnecessary dependencies, reducing potential attack vectors.

Follow Best Practices for Secure Coding

Adhering to secure coding practices is fundamental in developing resilient software that is resistant to attacks.

  1. Adopt a Security Coding Standard: Follow a coding standard focused on security, such as the OWASP Secure Coding Practices, to minimize the introduction of new vulnerabilities.
  2. Perform Code Reviews: Implement a peer review process where code is examined by one or more developers other than the author. This helps catch security flaws, bugs, and ensures adherence to coding standards.
  3. Educate Your Team: Regularly train developers on secure coding practices, emerging vulnerabilities, and defensive programming techniques. Consider conducting security awareness sessions and workshops.
  4. Use Static Analysis Security Testing (SAST): Integrate SAST tools into your development process to automatically analyze source code for potential security issues.
  5. Dynamic Analysis Security Testing (DAST): Use DAST tools to test your applications in runtime, simulating attacks on live applications to identify vulnerabilities that static analysis might miss.

References and Good Practices

  • OWASP: Utilize resources from the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) for the latest in web application security, including the OWASP Top Ten, which outlines the most critical web application security risks.
  • Keep Documentation: Document your security practices, dependency management policies, and update procedures. This helps maintain consistency and ensures new team members can follow established protocols.
  • Regular Security Assessments: Beyond just dependency management and secure coding, conduct regular security assessments, including penetration testing, to identify and mitigate risks.

By systematically updating dependencies, using dependency scanning tools, and adhering to secure coding practices, you can significantly enhance the security posture of your software projects, protecting both your data and your users.

threat.name: Attackers may exploit weaknesses in authentication and authorization mechanisms
threat.desc:
Weaknesses in authentication and authorization mechanisms represent significant security vulnerabilities within web-based user interfaces. These weaknesses can allow unauthorized access to sensitive information and systems. Authentication weaknesses pertain to flaws in verifying the identity of users attempting to access a service. Authorization weaknesses involve inadequacies in controlling what authenticated users are allowed to do. Together, these vulnerabilities can be exploited to gain unauthorized access or escalate privileges within a system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: The agents can range from automated scripts (bots) scanning the internet for vulnerabilities to exploit, to malicious insiders with legitimate access trying to elevate their privileges. External attackers, including cybercriminals and state-sponsored actors, may also exploit these weaknesses for various purposes.
  • Attack Vectors: Common attack vectors include credential stuffing, where attackers use previously breached username and password pairs to gain unauthorized access; phishing attacks aimed at tricking users into disclosing their credentials; and exploitation of implementation flaws in authentication mechanisms (e.g., bypassing multi-factor authentication) or authorization schemes (e.g., exploiting insecure direct object references to access unauthorized resources).

Impacts

The exploitation of weaknesses in authentication and authorization mechanisms can lead to several adverse impacts, including:

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive personal or business data, leading to loss of confidentiality.
  • Privilege Escalation: Attackers gaining higher-level access than what is authorized, potentially leading to full system compromise.
  • Reputation Damage: The loss of customer trust and damage to the organization's reputation following a security breach.
  • Financial Loss: Direct financial loss from theft or fraud, and indirect costs associated with incident response, legal fees, and potential fines for regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a web application does not properly enforce password complexity requirements. They use a brute-force attack to guess weak passwords and gain unauthorized access to multiple user accounts.
  • Scenario 2: A web application uses predictable resource IDs for user profiles. An authenticated attacker modifies the URL to an ID they do not own, directly accessing and altering another user’s profile due to improper authorization checks.
  • Scenario 3: An attacker performs a phishing campaign, sending emails to users of a web application, tricking them into clicking a link that leads to a fake login page designed to steal their credentials. Once successful, the attacker uses these credentials to gain unauthorized access to the web application.

Mitigating these threats requires implementing robust authentication mechanisms, such as multi-factor authentication, enforcing strong password policies, and regularly auditing and updating authorization logic to ensure that users can only access resources appropriate for their privilege level. Regular security assessments and awareness training for users can also significantly reduce the risk of such attacks.

threat.name: Attackers can deceive users into clicking on hidden elements
threat.desc:
This threat involves manipulating the web user interface (UI) to deceive users into clicking on elements that are not what they appear to be. This form of attack, often referred to as "clickjacking," uses various techniques to trick a user into clicking on a concealed or disguised element. These elements, when clicked, can trigger unauthorized actions, such as liking a page, sharing sensitive information, or granting permissions to access data or perform actions on the user's behalf. The attack leverages the trust a user has in the visible UI, exploiting it to facilitate actions unintended by the user and unauthorized by the system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: The primary agents behind these attacks are often cybercriminals aiming to exploit user trust for malicious purposes, ranging from spreading malware to executing phishing campaigns or stealing credentials.
  • Attack Vectors: Common vectors include:
    • UI Redressing: Overlaying transparent or cleverly disguised iframes over seemingly benign web pages.
    • Click Transparent Layer: Placing a transparent layer over a web page so that clicks intended for visible elements beneath are hijacked.
    • Cursor Hijacking: Altering the appearance or behavior of the cursor to deceive users about the actual point of click.

Impacts

The impacts of deceiving users into clicking on hidden elements can be widespread, affecting both individual users and organizations, including:

  • Privacy Violations: Unauthorized sharing of personal or sensitive information without the user's knowledge.
  • Account Compromise: Unintentional granting of access or permissions to attackers, leading to account takeover or data breaches.
  • Malware Infection: Users might inadvertently download and install malware, leading to further exploitation.
  • Reputational Damage: Organizations may suffer reputational damage due to the exploitation of their platforms for such attacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: A user visits a seemingly harmless website that has been compromised with a clickjacking script. The script overlays a transparent iframe over a "Play" button for a video. Instead of playing the video, clicking the button unknowingly shares a malicious link on the user's social media profile.
  • Scenario 2: An attacker designs a webpage that mimics a popular game. However, hidden within the game's UI is a disguised button that, when clicked, triggers the download of a piece of malware. The malware is executed unwittingly by the user, compromising their system.
  • Scenario 3: On a compromised e-commerce site, attackers overlay a transparent layer over the entire webpage. When users attempt to click on legitimate items, they instead click on this invisible layer, which redirects them to a phishing site designed to steal their credentials.

To mitigate these threats, developers can employ various strategies, such as implementing frame-busting scripts, enabling Content Security Policy (CSP) headers to prevent unauthorized framing, and educating users about the risks of clickjacking and similar deceptive practices. Additionally, regular security assessments of web applications can help identify and rectify vulnerabilities that could be exploited in such attacks.
